author: tobiwo
content:
Hi, I know this is a pretty trivial question for you guys but I couldn't find an clear answer on all the resources I read so far (shame on me, I skipped the paper ðŸ˜œ ) so I assume you can help me.
If network activity is high and the BASEFEE increases with every block, what happens to the BASEFEE for the first block which is less than 50% packed (let's say block N+1)? Does it decrease to the BASEFEE which was present in block N-1 (or by 12.5%) or does it drop to a kind of base level and starting all over again to rise if network activity goes up? I think the latter doesn't make sense while thinking briefly about it but maybe I'm missing something. Thanks for your help.

author: abdel.stark
content: If the gas used of block N is > 50% of the target gas used of block N then the base fee of block N +1 will be base fee of block N + fee delta where fee delta is between 0-12,5% of the base fee of block N

author: abdel.stark
content: If the gas used of block N is < 50% of the target gas used of block N then the base fee of block N +1 will be base fee of block N - fee delta where fee delta is between 0-12,5% of the base fee of block N

author: abdel.stark
content: And fee delta is proportional to the gas delta between block N and block N +1

author: tobiwo
content:
Ahh, ok. Thanks a ton.
Just another short question with regards to your reply, because this is new to me as well.
If block N is packed with 14 million gas and N+1 is packed with 20 million the BASEFEE on block N+1 would be: BASEFEE of N + (BASEFEE of N * 0.06). Is that correct?

author: abdel.stark
content: the exact formula is `base_fee_per_gas_delta = parent_base_fee_per_gas * gas_used_delta // parent_gas_target // BASE_FEE_MAX_CHANGE_DENOMINATOR`

author: abdel.stark
content: You can check details https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-1559 in Specification section
